title: Liverpool's Nike kit deal terms emerge as Reds battle New Balance in court

Nike are set to pay Liverpool an initial fee of £30million per season.

Liverpool and the sportswear giants are set to reach a record-breaking agreement over the club's kit deal from the 2020-21 season.

Liverpool's current deal with New Balance expires at the end of this season but the Premier League leaders have been dragged to court by their current supplier.

New Balance claim that they have triggered a “matching clause” in the contract, which would see them retain the agreement, but Liverpool claim they haven't replicated Nike's terms.

It emerged in London’s Commercial Court on Friday that Nike will pay Liverpool a flat fee of £30m per season but the club's projections mean that could reach £70m a year, reports the Athletic.

(Image: Publicity Picture)

There is also bonuses for their on-field success - £4m for winning the Champions League and £2m for winning the Premier League.

Liverpool have also been pledged royalties of 20 percent of all net sales of merchandise, £2m worth of licensed products per season - and a 19 percent discount on standard wholesale prices.

Liverpool's current deal with New Balance is currently worth around £40m-a-year to the club.

Nike have vowed to sell the club's kit in at least 6,000 stores across the world and have already invested in almost £4.5m on material for next season's strip.

Designs for replica and training kits have already been agreed while those for 2021/22 are also close to being finalised.

Any court ruling is set to depend heavily on whether New Balance can match Nike's guarantees, which at present seems unlikely.
description: Liverpool have been dragged to court by current supplier New Balance, whose deal expires at the end of the season
